title: Ivar Giaever
text:
Ivar Giaever (, ; born April 5, 1929) is a Norwegian-American engineer and physicist who shared the <a href="Nobel%20Prize%20in%20Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a> in 1973 with <a href="Leo%20Esaki">Leo Esaki</a> and <a href="Brian%20David%20Josephson">Brian Josephson</a> "for their discoveries regarding <a href="Quantum%20tunnelling">tunnelling phenomena</a> in <a href="solid-state%20physics">solids</a>". Giaever's share of the prize was specifically for his "experimental discoveries regarding tunnelling phenomena in <a href="Superconductivity">superconductors</a>". 
In 1975, he was elected as a member into the <a href="National%20Academy%20of%20Engineering">National Academy of Engineering</a> for contributions in the discovery and elaboration of electron tunneling into superconductors.
Giaever is a <a href="professor%20emeritus">professor emeritus</a> at the <a href="Rensselaer%20Polytechnic%20Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> and the president of the company Applied Biophysics.
Early life.
Giaever earned a degree in <a href="mechanical%20engineering">mechanical engineering</a> from the <a href="Norwegian%20University%20of%20Science%20and%20Technology">Norwegian Institute of Technology</a> in Trondheim in 1952. In 1954, he emigrated from Norway to Canada, where he was employed by the Canadian division of <a href="General%20Electric">General Electric</a>. He moved to the United States four years later, joining <a href="General%20Electric%20Research%20Laboratory">General Electric's Corporate Research and Development Center</a> in Schenectady, New York, in 1958. He has lived in <a href="Niskayuna%2C%20New%20York">Niskayuna, New York</a>, since then, taking up US citizenship in 1964. While working for General Electric, Giaever earned a <a href="Doctor%20of%20Philosophy">Ph.D.</a> degree at the <a href="Rensselaer%20Polytechnic%20Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in 1964.
The Nobel Prize.
The work that led to Giaever's Nobel Prize was performed at General Electric in 1960. Following on Esaki's discovery of <a href="electron">electron</a> tunnelling in <a href="semiconductor">semiconductor</a>s in 1958, Giaever showed that tunnelling also took place in superconductors, demonstrating tunnelling through a very thin layer of <a href="oxide">oxide</a> surrounded on both sides by <a href="metal">metal</a> in a superconducting or normal state. Giaever's experiments demonstrated the existence of an <a href="energy%20gap">energy gap</a> in superconductors, one of the most important predictions of the <a href="BCS%20theory">BCS theory</a> of superconductivity, which had been developed in 1957. Giaever's experimental demonstration of tunnelling in superconductors stimulated the theoretical physicist Brian Josephson to work on the phenomenon, leading to his prediction of the <a href="Josephson%20effect">Josephson effect</a> in 1962. Esaki and Giaever shared half of the 1973 Nobel Prize, and Josephson received the other half.
Giaever's research later in his career was mainly in the field of <a href="biophysics">biophysics</a>. In 1969, he researched biophysics for a year as a fellow at <a href="Clare%20Hall%2C%20Cambridge">Clare Hall</a>, <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a>, through a Guggenheim Fellowship, and he continued to work in this area after he returned to the US.
He has co-signed a letter from over 70 Nobel laureate scientists to the Louisiana Legislature supporting the repeal of <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>’s <a href="Louisiana%20Science%20Education%20Act">Louisiana Science Education Act</a>.
Other prizes.
In addition to the Nobel Prize, he has also been awarded the <a href="Buckley%20Prize">Oliver E. Buckley Prize</a> by the <a href="American%20Physical%20Society">American Physical Society</a> in 1965, the Golden Plate Award of the <a href="Academy%20of%20Achievement">American Academy of Achievement</a> in 1966, and the <a href="Zworykin%20Award">Zworykin Award</a> by the <a href="National%20Academy%20of%20Engineering">National Academy of Engineering</a> in 1975.
In 1985, he was awarded an <a href="honorary%20degree">honorary degree</a>, doctor honoris causa, at the <a href="Norwegian%20Institute%20of%20Technology">Norwegian Institute of Technology</a>, later part of <a href="Norwegian%20University%20of%20Science%20and%20Technology">Norwegian University of Science and Technology</a>.
He is a member of the <a href="Norwegian%20Academy%20of%20Science%20and%20Letters">Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters</a>.
Global warming.
Giaever has repeatedly professed skepticism of <a href="global%20warming">global warming</a>, calling it a "new religion."
On 13 September 2011, Giaever resigned from the <a href="American%20Physical%20Society">American Physical Society</a> over its official position. The APS Fellow noted: "In the APS it is ok to discuss whether the mass of the proton changes over time and how a multi-universe behaves, but the evidence of global warming is incontrovertible?"
Giaever is currently a science advisor with American <a href="Conservatism%20in%20the%20United%20States">conservative</a> and <a href="Libertarianism%20in%20the%20United%20States">libertarian</a> <a href="think%20tank">think tank</a> <a href="The%20Heartland%20Institute">The Heartland Institute</a>.
Personal life.
Giaever married his childhood sweetheart Inger Skramstad in 1952. They have four children: John, Anne, Guri and Trine. Giaever is an atheist.
